metadata.titleEn: Organic matter data from Wulungu Lake in Xinjiang over the past 8000 years
metadata.description: This dataset includes organic matter data of Wulungu Lake in Xinjiang. The area is a closed terminal lake, fed mainly by meltwater from snow and ice, and today the climate in the area is dominated by westerlies. The collected lake core was divided into samples at 1 cm spacing, freeze-dried and sampled, and tested by Muffle furnace. Take cleaning, drying crucible weighing; Weigh the sample and place it in the crucible. Record the total weight of the sample and crucible. The sample is placed in the Muffle furnace, heated to 550℃ and kept for 2 hours, and the crucible is taken out and cooled in the dryer after cooling to the appropriate temperature. After reaching the constant weight, the percentage of the weight of the burned part to the dry weight of the sample is the burned loss. The burning vector was converted to organic matter content by linear formula. With the superposition of centennial scale changes, the water vapor content has gradually increased since 8000 cal BP. 8000 ~ 5350 cal yr BP forms a permanent lake, the surface of which gradually rises. The humidity increases rapidly between 5350 and 500 cal yr BP, with the wettest climate occurring between 3200 and 500 cal yr BP. After 500 cal yr BP, the lake level drops. The trend of increasing humidity in Holocene indicates that the winter precipitation in northern Xinjiang was on the rise during Holocene.

literatureList.titleEn: Moisture evolution in North Xinjiang (northwest China) during the last 8000 years linked to the westerlies’ winter half-year precipitation
literatureList.referenceEn: Zhang, X., Zhou, A., Huang, Z., An, C., Zhao, Y., Yin, L., & Russell, J. M. (2020). Moisture evolution in North Xinjiang (northwest China) during the last 8000 years linked to the westerlies’ winter half-year precipitation. Quaternary Research, 100, 122–134. doi:10.1017/qua.2020.94

fundVOList.titleEn: National Key Research and Development Program of China

projectList.titleEn: National Tibetan Plateau / Third Pole Environment Data Center

background: Winter half-year precipitation dominates variations in hydroclimatic conditions in North Xinjiang, but few researchers have focused on this very important aspect of the Holocene climate. The site is a closed terminal lake fed mainly by meltwater from snow and ice, and today the area is climatically dominated by the westerlies.
research objective: Here we report multiproxy evidence of Holocene hydroclimate changes from the sediments of Wulungu Lake in North Xinjiang.
challenges: The dating of bulk organic matter (BOM) may be influenced by the reservoir effect and result in old radiocarbon ages of samples.
methods: In September 2010, two parallel sediment cores were recovered from the northeast part of Wulungu Lake (47° 21′ 50.50′′ N, 87°27′ 7.20′′E), in a water depth of 15.47 m, using a custom-built piston corer on a UWITEC platform. The first section was 280 cm in sediment depth and was collected using a self-made piston that was assembled with two rubber plugs (each measuring 60 mm in diameter), four steel plates (each measuring 58 mm in diameter), and a steel pin. The second section was 132 cm in sediment depth and was collected using a UWITEC 60-mm piston. Both sections of core WLG10B were split into two halves: one half was used for X-ray fluorescence (XRF) scanning, and the other half was subsampled at 1-cm intervals and freeze-dried for further investigation. The intact half-core was carefully flattened and then imaged with a line scan camera on an Avaatech XRF core scanner with a resolution of 140 ppcm (350 dpi); it was then covered with Ultralene plastic film (4μm) and analyzed again using the same core scanner. The total organic matter (TOM) content was determined using weight loss-on-ignition measurements at 1-cm intervals. Three samples from different lithological facies and samples from the lakeshore and the Wulungu River were used for X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis using a PANalytical X’Pert Pro MPD. For grain-size analysis, the sediments were subsampled at 1-cm intervals and pretreated with 10% H2O2 to remove organic matter and then with 10% HCl to remove carbonates. Finally, the samples were rinsed with deionized water and dispersed with 10 ml of 0.05 mol/L (NaPO3)6 on an ultrasonic vibrator for 10 mins. Grain-size distributions (GSDs) between 0.02 μm and 2000 μm were measured using a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser grain-size analyzer and assigned to 100 size classes.
findings: Grain-size end-member analysis implies an important mode of variation that indicates a gradually increasing moisture trend, with superimposed centennial-scale variations, since 8000 cal yr BP. From 8000 to 5350 cal yr BP, a permanent lake developed, and the lake level gradually rose. Between 5350 and 500 cal yr BP, the moisture status increased rapidly, with the wettest climate occurring between 3200 and 500 cal yr BP. After 500 cal yr BP, the lake level fell. The trend of increasing Holocene wetness indicates a rising winter precipitation in North Xinjiang during the Holocene. This was due to an increase in upwind vapor concentrations caused by increased evaporation and strength of the westerlies, which were determined by the increasing boreal winter insolation and its latitudinal gradient.

Verification.Question: Can the process of using weight loss-on-ignition measurements at 1-cm intervals accurately determine the total organic matter content in sediment cores?
Is the linear formula used to convert burn vector to organic matter content a reliable method in this field?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the determination of organic matter content in sediment cores more accurately achieved using loss-on-ignition measurements, XRF scanning, or XRD analysis?
When collecting sediment cores for hydroclimate analysis, is it more effective to use a custom-built piston corer, a UWITEC platform, or another coring approach?
Disjunctive.Answer: custom-built piston corer on a UWITEC platform

Concept Completion.Question: What are the common methods used for determining the total organic matter in lake sediment cores?
What challenges are associated with dating bulk organic matter in sediment cores?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to analyze organic matter content in lake sediment cores?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method for analyzing organic matter content in lake sediment cores involves subsampling the cores at 1-cm intervals, freeze-drying the samples, and then conducting weight loss-on-ignition measurements to determine the total organic matter content.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when dating bulk organic matter in sediment cores?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge encountered when dating bulk organic matter in sediment cores is the reservoir effect, which can influence the radiocarbon ages of the samples, potentially resulting in older apparent ages.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific methods used for organic matter content determination in lake sediment cores?
Feature Specification.Answer: 550°C, two hours, weight loss as a percentage of the dry sample weight

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges associated with dating sediment cores in closed terminal lakes?
What are the characteristics of the grain-size analysis process in lake sediments?
Feature Specification.Answer: subsampling at 1-cm intervals, pretreatment with 10% H2O2, pretreatment with 10% HCl, rinsing with deionized water, dispersion with sodium hexametaphosphate, ultrasonic vibration, laser grain-size analysis, grain-size distribution measurement between 0.02 μm and 2000 μm

Quantification.Question: How many sediment cores were recovered from the data collection site in North Xinjiang?
What is the resolution of the line scan camera used for imaging the sediment cores?
Quantification.Answer: 140 pixels per centimeter, 350 dots per inch

Quantification.Question: How many size classes were assigned to the grain-size distributions measured in the sediment analysis?

Definition.Question: What does 'weight loss-on-ignition' mean in the context of organic matter content determination?
Definition.Answer: Weight loss-on-ignition is a method used to determine the total organic matter content in sediment samples. It involves subjecting the sample to high temperatures in a muffle furnace, where it is heated to 550°C for 2 hours. The percentage of the weight lost during this process, relative to the dry weight of the sample, is calculated to estimate the organic matter content.

Definition.Question: What is the 'reservoir effect' in the context of radiocarbon dating bulk organic matter?
Definition.Answer: The reservoir effect in radiocarbon dating refers to the potential for bulk organic matter dating to be influenced by older carbon sources, which can result in dated samples appearing older than they actually are. This occurs when organic material from sources such as sediments, which may contain 'old' carbon, is incorporated into the sample being dated.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the organic matter study of Wulungu Lake compare to other common methodologies for lake sediment analysis?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods for Wulungu Lake involved using piston corers to recover sediment cores, subsampling at 1-cm intervals, and performing X-ray fluorescence scanning, which are fairly standard in lake sediment analysis. Other methodologies might use different coring techniques, intervals, or additional analyses like carbon dating or isotopic studies to complement organic matter analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the potential inaccuracies in the dating of bulk organic matter (BOM) in sediment cores, and how might these factors affect the overall data collection process?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The dating of bulk organic matter (BOM) may be influenced by the reservoir effect, which can result in old radiocarbon ages of samples. This potential inaccuracy can affect the overall data collection process by introducing errors in the chronological framework, impacting the interpretation of hydroclimatic changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the trend of increasing Holocene wetness in North Xinjiang, and how does it relate to the data collected from sediment cores?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The trend of increasing Holocene wetness in North Xinjiang is caused by a rise in winter precipitation due to increased upwind vapor concentrations and strength of the westerlies, influenced by boreal winter insolation and its latitudinal gradient. This trend is inferred from grain-size end-member analysis of sediment cores, which indicates a gradually increasing moisture trend since 8000 cal yr BP.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the dating reservoir effect influence the interpretation of hydroclimate trends derived from organic matter in lake sediments?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The dating reservoir effect can lead to older radiocarbon ages of organic matter samples, potentially skewing the interpretation of hydroclimate trends and requiring careful calibration to ensure accurate chronological frameworks.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind collecting organic matter data from sediment cores in closed terminal lakes in North Xinjiang?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to report multiproxy evidence of Holocene hydroclimate changes, focusing on understanding variations in hydroclimatic conditions dominated by winter half-year precipitation, which are crucial for interpreting the climatic history of the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address challenges such as the reservoir effect when dating bulk organic matter in sediment cores?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing challenges like the reservoir effect is important because it can influence the dating accuracy, potentially leading to old radiocarbon ages, which could misrepresent the timeline of climatic events and hinder the correct interpretation of historical hydroclimatic changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in using a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser grain-size analyzer to measure grain-size distributions in sediment samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involve subsampling sediments at 1-cm intervals, pretreating the samples with 10% H2O2 to remove organic matter, and 10% HCl to remove carbonates. The samples are then rinsed with deionized water and dispersed with 10 ml of 0.05 mol/L (NaPO3)6 on an ultrasonic vibrator for 10 minutes. Grain-size distributions are measured using a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser grain-size analyzer, which assigns the sediment to 100 size classes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the weight loss-on-ignition method applied to determine the total organic matter content in lake sediment samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The weight loss-on-ignition method involves collecting sediment cores and splitting them into halves. One half is subsampled at 1-cm intervals and freeze-dried. The sample is then weighed before and after being placed in a muffle furnace at 550°C for 2 hours. The weight loss is calculated as a percentage of the dry weight to determine the total organic matter content.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures are followed for X-ray fluorescence (XRF) scanning of sediment cores to analyze their composition?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: For X-ray fluorescence (XRF) scanning, sediment cores are first split into two halves. The intact half-core is carefully flattened and imaged with a line scan camera on an Avaatech XRF core scanner with a resolution of 140 ppcm (350 dpi). It is then covered with Ultralene plastic film (4μm) and analyzed again using the same core scanner to determine the composition.

Expectation.Question: Why would some data collection methods potentially result in unexpected dating inaccuracies?
Expectation.Answer: The dating of bulk organic matter (BOM) in the dataset may be influenced by the reservoir effect, which can lead to unexpectedly old radiocarbon ages of samples, thus introducing potential inaccuracies in dating.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using a custom-built piston corer and a UWITEC platform for sediment core recovery in hydrological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Using a custom-built piston corer and a UWITEC platform appears effective for sediment core recovery, given the successful extraction of cores from Wulungu Lake at specific depths. The method provided detailed samples for multiproxy analysis, proving useful in interpreting historical hydroclimate changes.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges associated with the reservoir effect influencing the dating of bulk organic matter in paleoclimate studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The reservoir effect poses significant challenges in dating bulk organic matter, potentially leading to inaccuracies in radiocarbon dating due to older apparent ages. Researchers need to consider this effect when interpreting chronological data to ensure reliable results.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the potential of grain-size end-member analysis in revealing historical moisture trends in terminal lake environments?
Judgmental.Answer: Grain-size end-member analysis is a valuable tool for identifying historical moisture trends in terminal lake environments. It effectively highlighted a gradually increasing moisture trend with centennial-scale variations in the Wulungu Lake study, offering insights into past climate conditions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the technique of using a custom-built piston corer contributes to the accuracy and reliability of sediment core collection for climate study.
Assertion.Answer: The use of a custom-built piston corer allows for precise collection of sediment cores, minimizing disturbances and ensuring the integrity of the samples. This is crucial for accurately analyzing the sediment layers and obtaining reliable data about historical climate conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the challenges involved in dating sediment samples in Holocene climate studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: One challenge in dating sediment samples is the influence of the reservoir effect on the dating of bulk organic matter (BOM), which can result in older radiocarbon ages for samples, complicating the accurate reconstruction of past climatic conditions.
